description: Once a working class neighbourhood, Shoreditch has evolved since the 90s from an artistic hub to a hyper gentrified caricature of itself.
content1: Exit Hoxton Station, turn left on Geffrye St, turn left on Pearson St, and left again on Kingsland Rd. You will pass the **Museum of the Home**, a free exhibit exploring home life from 1600 to the present day. Continue up Kingsland Rd, turning left on Old St. To your right is **Shoreditch Church**, mentioned in the line "When I grow rich, say the bells of Shoreditch" from the nursery rhyme Oranges & Lemons. Turn right on Austin St, through Hocker St, reaching **Arnold Circus**. Built in 1890 the Boundary Estate here is one of the earliest social housing projects in England.
content2: Exit Arnold Circus on Calvert Ave, coming out on Shoreditch High St. Turn left and take the first right onto Rivington St, passing **Banksy’s “designated graffiti area”** on your right. Coming out onto Great Eastern St, turn left, passing the **Old Blue Last** music venue. Above an old viaduct you will spot two disused tube trains covered in graffiti, now acting as a co-working space for artists called **Village Underground**. Turn left on Shoreditch High St and right onto Bethnal Green Rd. On your right is **Boxpark**, Shoreditch’s shipping container palace of gentrification.
content3: Continue up Bethnal Green Rd and turn left on **Brick Lane**. On Sundays the street is home to a bustling market selling prints, vinyl, antique books and street food. The **Truman Market** is located within the old Truman brewery, whose chimney towers above Brick Ln. Further down the street are many East End curry houses, outside which hawkers will try to lure you into their restaurants. Follow Brick Ln as it turns into Osborn St, emerging on Whitechapel High St. Turn right, where you can find **[Whitechapel Gallery](https://master.d2vfdnjt990bte.amplifyapp.com/sights/whitechapel-gallery)**. An entrance to Aldgate East tube station is next to the gallery.
author: Michael Tandy
aboutTheAuthor: Michael Tandy is a developer, illustrator and travel enthusiast.

description: Canterbury is the seat of English Christianity and for centuries a pilgrimage site for those visiting the shrine of St Thomas Beckett.
content1: Exiting the train station, cross Canterbury E Station Bridge onto the roman **City Wall**. Turn left towards Castle Row and a path will take you to **Canterbury Castle**, built after the battle of Hastings. Turn back on yourself so that you’re on the City Wall again and walk in the direction of the **Simmon’s Memorial** which sits on Dane John Mound. You will see **Dane John Gardens** below. Exit Dane John Gardens onto Watling St and turn left, continuing to the roundabout. Turn right on Rose Ln and continue until you reach the Parade/High St.
content2: Turn left, then take a right at Butchery Ln towards **Canterbury Cathedral**. On Burgate, take a left towards Canterbury Cathedral Gate and explore the *[World Heritage Site](https://master.d2vfdnjt990bte.amplifyapp.com/sights/canterbury-cathedral)*. Exiting the Cathedral take a right onto Sun St/Palace St. Note the historic buildings, including the **Crooked House** at the street’s end. Turn left and continue up King’s St/Best Ln until reach the High St. To your left is the **Beaney House of Art & Knowledge**, the city’s museum & gallery, and to your right is the **Eastbridge Hospital**, built in the 12th century to provide accommodation for pilgrims.
content3: Take a left, then turn right onto Stour St, then turn right on Water Ln. The **Canterbury Punting Company** is on the right where you can book a river tour on the River Stour. Cross the bridge into Greyfriars Gardens and find the **Greyfriars Franciscan Chapel**, built during the lifetime of St Francis of Assisi. Visitors are welcome, a small donation can be made at the door. Retrace your steps until you’re on the High St and take a left towards **Westgate**. Continue up St Dunstan’s St and take a right at Station Road West, finishing at Canterbury West Train Station.
author: Michael Tandy
aboutTheAuthor: Michael Tandy is a developer, illustrator and travel enthusiast.

description: Camden Town is a unique hub of creativity and alternative culture, and is home to a world famous market.
content1: Exit Mornington Crescent tube station and to your left you will see the **Carreras Cigarette Factory**, an art deco building that stands as a striking example of Egyptian-revival architecture, and distinguished by a pair of 8-foot high bronze statues of the Egyptian cat goddess Bastet. Turn right and continue down Camden High Street, passing the famous **Koko** nightclub, a former theatre that serves as one of London’s premier music venues.
content2: Taking a left on Delancey St, then a right on Albert St will lead you to the **Jewish Museum**, which stores examples of Jewish ceremonial art. Exiting the museum turn left, coming out on Parkway, turn left again, then turn right on **Gloucester Crescent**, dubbed “Britain’s cleverest street”, with former residents including Alan Bennett. His house (#23) is the place where Margaret Fairchild, a homeless woman in a van, lived on his driveway for 15 years, which later became the subject of the 2015 film The Lady in the Van. Turn right onto Inverness St.
content3: Pass through Inverness St Market back onto Camden High St and turn left. On your right you will see *‘The Camden Market’*, but the famous market is further on. Crossing over **Regent’s Canal** and turning left will take you into **Camden Lock Markets**. These adjoining retail markets sell clothing, food and bric-a-brac. Pushing further into the market brings you to the **Stables Market**, a former horse hospital now selling antiques and oddities. **Cyberdog** is a memorable store. Exit onto Camden High St and go back the way you came, finishing the walk at Camden Town tube station.
author: Michael Tandy
aboutTheAuthor: Michael Tandy is a developer, illustrator and travel enthusiast.

description: This walk takes you through the Heart of the City, a major redevelopment of Sheffield’s center completed in 2016.
content1: Exit Sheffield Station. Follow the **steel water feature** along Sheaf Sq and turn right at the pedestrian crossing. Continue up Sheaf Sq as it turns into Howard St and turn right on Arundel Gate. Follow the footpath outside the *Millennium Gallery* up to Surrey St. On your right is the **Central Library**, a 1929 art deco building containing the **Graves Art Gallery**, housing collections of historic and contemporary art. On Tudor Sq is the **Crucible Theatre**, home to the World Snooker Championship, and the **Lyceum**, an Edwardian theatre which hosts touring West End productions.
content2: To your left is the **Winter Garden**, one of the largest temperate glasshouses in Europe and home to 2000 plants from around the world. You can enter the **Millenium Gallery** from here, which includes the *metalwork collection* comprising 13,000 objects made of Sheffield steel. Exit the Winter Garden onto St Paul’s Pl, turn right and enter the **Peace Gardens**. Looming over is **Sheffield Town Hall**, opened by Queen Victoria in 1897 and still a municipal building. On Pinstone St turn right, and follow Pinstone St as it turns into Surrey St, turning left on Fargate.
content3: Continue down Fargate, reaching Church St. To your left is **Sheffield Cathedral**, an unusual mixture of medieval and modern architecture dating from 1200 to 1966. Follow High St / Commercial St. On your right is **Ponds Forge**, home to an Olympic sized swimming pool, and straight ahead looms **Park Hill flats**, an undemolishable Grade II listed post war brutalist building. Turn right on Sheaf St. **Sheffield Tap**, an Edwardian refreshment room containing a huge selection of craft beers and ciders, offers an entrance to the station and an exit straight onto platform 1b.
author: Michael Tandy
aboutTheAuthor: Michael Tandy is a developer, illustrator and travel enthusiast.
iframeTitle: Sheffield Heart of the City Google Map

description: The center of Leeds blends modern developments with its Victorian roots in Yorkshire’s most populous city.
content1: Exit Leeds Station onto New Station St. Turn left on Wellington St, then turn right onto Park Row. To your right is a **statue of the Black Prince** (despite having no connection to Leeds), and left is the gothic unitarian **Mill Hill Chapel**. Joseph Priestley, the man who discovered oxygen, once ministered here. Turn right on the footpath beside the chapel and enter the **Trinity Shopping Cente**r. A *sculpture of a pack horse* can be seen in the central court, and exiting on Briggate, a *sculpture of Minerva*, the goddess of weaving and commerce, can be seen outside.
content2: Turn left on Boar Ln / Duncan St. Ahead is **[Leeds Corn Exchange](https://master.d2vfdnjt990bte.amplifyapp.com/sights/leeds-corn-exchange)**, one of a few buildings of its kind in the UK and now a boutique shopping center for independent retailers, selling vinyl, clothing and craft beer. Exit the Corn Exchange and turn right on New Market St. You will approach **Kirkgate Market** on your left, home to the first *Marks & Spencer*, where the company still operates a **historic penny bazaar**. Continue up Vicar Ln. This area includes **Victoria Quarter**, a district of interconnected contemporary and restored Victorian shopping arcades.
content3: Exit the Victoria Quarter onto Briggate, turning right, then left on Headrow. At the intersection between Headrow and Park Row is the **Henry Moore Institute**, a modern sculpture exhibition, and next to it is **Leeds Art Gallery and Central Library**, which houses the grand **tiled hall café**. Admission is free for all of the above. Beside the library is **Leeds Town Hall**, imagined as a municipal palace to demonstrate the power and success of Victorian Leeds. Turning back on Park Row, continue towards Leeds Train Station, where the walk ends.
author: Michael Tandy
aboutTheAuthor: Michael Tandy is a developer, illustrator and travel enthusiast.

description: Budapest is an affordable city with great history and architecture, vibrant nightlife and a laid back feel.
content1: Exit the station, turn left on Károly Krt, then right onto Wesselényi St. On your right you will see the **Donáhy St Synagogue**, the largest synagogue in Europe. Its architect Ludwig Förster believed no distinctively Jewish architecture could be identified, modelling it instead on Islamic styles. Donáhy St itself constituted the border of the Budapest ghetto, within which you can find Budapest’s famous ruin bars. Turning right on Kazinczy St, you will find **Szimpla Kert**, Budapest’s first ruin bar; a vast space with capacity for 600, but with a quirky popup feel.
content2: Turn right on Rákóczi Rd. On your left is Pest’s **Palace District**, and turning right on Múzeum Kert is the **Hungarian National Museum**. Continue onto Kálvin Sq, approaching the Liberty Bridge. On your left is the **Great Market Hall**, the largest and oldest indoor market in the city, designed to improve the city’s food supply with the objective that only food that had been inspected should be sold. It is still a food market selling meats, pastries, candies, spices, and spirits over three floors.
content3: Continue across the **Liberty Bridge**, which connects Buda and Pest across the **Danube river**. The bridge was completed in 1896 and opened by the Emperor Franz Joseph, and is a great place from which to watch the sunset. To your right is **Gellért Hill**, which can be ascended on foot. At the top of the hill is the **statue of liberty**, erected in 1947 in remembrance of the Soviet liberation of Hungary during WWII. This vantage point offers some of the best views of the city.
author: Michael Tandy
aboutTheAuthor: Michael Tandy is a developer, illustrator and travel enthusiast.
